questions.text: Which of the following constitutes Hutchinson's triad? (AIIMS NOV 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry molars

options.label: B
options.text: Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson molars

options.label: C
options.text: Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry incisors

options.label: D
options.text: Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson incisors

questions.correct_answer: D. Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson incisors
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson incisors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hutchinson's triad consists of interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, and Hutchinson incisors, and it is a diagnostic feature of late congenital syphilis.

questions.text: A child is brought to the hospital with features of respiratory distress and biphasic stridor. There is a history of upper respiratory infection. The radiograph is shown below. Mark the correct diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) is a viral infection of the glottis and subglottic region, often caused by the Parainfluenza virus, and presents with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of some dehydration in a 5-year-old child? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lethargy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, whereas delayed skin pinch and sunken eyeballs can be signs of both some and severe dehydration in a 5-year-old child.

questions.text: Which of the following milestones would you generally expect a 3-year-old child to display? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Spoon handling

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ By the age of 3 years, a child is typically expected to handle a spoon and feed themselves, while more complex motor and language skills develop later.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child has difficulty walking and getting up from a squatting position. A muscle biopsy was done and is as shown in the image. Which of the following is true about this condition? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: C
options.text: It is a mitochondrial storage disorder

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Death occurs in 3rddecade

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness, and death typically occurs in the late teens to early 20s.

questions.text: Ponderal index is defined as: (AIIMS NOV 2016)

options.label: A
options.text: Square root of height in feet by weight in grams

options.label: B
options.text: Weight in kilograms by cube of height in meters

options.label: C
options.text: Mid-upper arm circumference to head circumference ratio

options.label: D
options.text: Head circumference to abdominal circumference ratio

questions.correct_answer: B. Weight in kilograms by cube of height in meters
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Ponderal Index (PI) is a measure used to assess the leanness or corpulence of a person, especially newborns. It is calculated by dividing the weight in kilograms by the cube of the height in meters. This index helps to distinguish between symmetric and asymmetric growth retardation in infants. A PI of less than 2 indicates asymmetric growth retardation, while a PI of 2 or more suggests normal or symmetric growth retardation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. square root of height in feet by weight in grams - This is not the correct formula for Ponderal Index.
  • • Option A. square root of height in feet by weight in grams
  • • Option C. Mid-upper arm circumference to head circumference ratio - This is a different anthropometric measurement.
  • • Option C. Mid-upper arm circumference to head circumference ratio
  • • Option D. Head circumference to abdominal circumference ratio - This is another anthropometric ratio used for different assessments.
  • • Option D. Head circumference to abdominal circumference ratio

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Ponderal Index is calculated as weight in kilograms divided by the cube of height in meters, used to assess growth patterns in infants.

questions.text: What are the recommended actions according to Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines for a baby born with meconium-stained amniotic fluid? (INICET MAY 2023) lntrapartum suction of nose and mouth before delivery of shoulder lntratracheal suction in case of non-vigorous baby Gentle suction of nose and mouth in case of vigorous baby PPV in case of non-vigorous baby after early steps
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a newborn with meconium-stained amniotic fluid, gentle suction is applied to the nose and mouth if the baby is vigorous, and PPV is administered if the baby is non-vigorous after the initial steps of resuscitation.

questions.text: An adolescent girl complains of dropping objects from hands precipitated during morning hours and exams. There is no history of loss of consciousness. One of her cousins has been diagnosed with epilepsy. EEG was suggestive of epileptic spikes. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME) is characterized by myoclonic jerks, typically occurring in the morning, with preserved consciousness and a good response to sodium valproate.

questions.text: Consider the following Statements? ( INICET Nov 2023) Statement 1- Contemplation – A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking Statement 2- Precontemplation – A person is considering starting morning walks and its benefits to the health Statement 3- Maintenance phase/determination phase – A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then Statement 4- Action phase – A person with obesity says he cant’s do anything as it runs deep in his family
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Statement 1 and 3 are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Behavior change – 6 stages –
  • ➤ Precontemplation → Contemplation → Preparation/ Determination → Action/will power → Maintenance → Termination

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom of severe dehydration? ( INICET MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Thirsty child.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A thirsty child indicates some dehydration, whereas signs like drowsiness, slow skin pinch retraction, and a sunken fontanelle are indicative of severe dehydration.

questions.text: A child in your unit is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). According to the WHO criteria, SAM is defined best by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.correct_answer: D. Weight for height less than - 3SD
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Weight for height less than -3SD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is defined by the WHO as weight-for-height (or length) below -3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards, presence of bilateral pitting edema, or mid-upper arm circumference less than 11.5 cm.

questions.text: Regarding urinary tract infection (UTI) in children, which of the following is true? (INICET MAY 2022) Most common cause of UTI is Streptococcus pneumoniae. Bowel, bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrence. Cotrimoxazole is not given. Micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU) is done in children with recurrence of UTI.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that bowel and bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrent UTIs in children, and that MCU is performed in cases of recurrent UTI to assess for anatomical and functional abnormalities.

questions.text: A preterm infant in the NICU was observed to have marked nasal flare, distinct xiphoid retractions, minimal intercostal retractions, and inspiratory lag with an audible grunt. What would be the Silverman Anderson score? ? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 8

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Silverman-Anderson score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in neonates, with a score of 8 indicating significant distress requiring close monitoring and possibly intervention.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with cyanosis and episodes of squatting during breathlessness. A chest X-ray is performed, revealing an abnormal heart shape. Based on the findings, which of the following best describes the chest X-ray image?

options.label: B
options.text: Boot-shaped heart due to right ventricular hypertrophy

options.label: C
options.text: Egg-on-a-string appearance due to transposition of the great arteries

options.label: D
options.text: Enlarged left atrium with double contour sign

questions.correct_answer: B. Boot-shaped heart due to right ventricular hypertrophy
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The chest X-ray image demonstrates a "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart, which is characteristic of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). This distinct appearance is due to right ventricular hypertrophy, which causes the cardiac apex to elevate, giving the heart a boot-like shape. TOF is a congenital heart defect that includes four key features: right ventricular hypertrophy, ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, and an overriding aorta.
  • • Key Points from Explanation Hint:
  • • Key Points from Explanation Hint:
  • • "Coeur en sabot" (Boot-shaped Heart): This term refers to the boot-like shape of the heart seen on X-ray due to elevation of the cardiac apex, resulting from right ventricular hypertrophy.
  • • "Coeur en sabot" (Boot-shaped Heart):
  • • Radiographic Features:
  • • Radiographic Features:
  • • The hilar areas and lung fields appear relatively clear due to diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries.
  • • The aorta is typically large, contributing to the overall radiographic appearance.
  • • Clinical Correlation:
  • • Clinical Correlation:
  • • Children with TOF may present with cyanosis and characteristic symptoms such as squatting during hypoxic episodes, which helps to temporarily increase systemic vascular resistance and improve oxygenation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Cardiomegaly with pulmonary edema: This finding typically shows an enlarged heart with fluid accumulation in the lungs, not seen in TOF.
  • • Option
  • • A) Cardiomegaly with pulmonary edema:
  • • Option C) Egg-on-a-string appearance: This is characteristic of transposition of the great arteries, marked by a narrow superior mediastinum.
  • • Option
  • • C) Egg-on-a-string appearance:
  • • Option D) Enlarged left atrium with double contour sign: Commonly seen in conditions like mitral stenosis, which are unrelated to TOF.
  • • Option
  • • D) Enlarged left atrium with double contour sign:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart seen on X-ray is characteristic of Tetralogy of Fallot, resulting from right ventricular hypertrophy. Recognizing this distinctive radiographic feature is essential for diagnosing TOF, a congenital heart condition requiring timely medical or surgical intervention to prevent severe complications.

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of fever, rash, body ache, and throat ache. He has a history of thorn prick injury a week back. What antibiotics would you give empirically to this child? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Amoxicilin +clavulanate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a child presenting with symptoms suggestive of scarlet fever following a thorn prick injury, empirical antibiotic treatment with amoxicillin + clavulanate is appropriate while awaiting diagnostic confirmation of Group A Streptococcus infection.

questions.text: A child presents with generalized edema and was found to have hypercholesterolemia. Urinalysis shows protein 3+ and fat bodies. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nephrotic syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, massive proteinuria, and fat bodies in urinalysis

questions.text: A child presents with fever and vesicular lesions on the upper limb and the lower limb. Neck stiffness was present. Similar lesions were present on the palms, soles, and oral cavity. CSF analysis revealed normal glucose levels and elevated lymphocytes and protein. What is the most likely diagnosis? ( INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: B
options.text: Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

questions.correct_answer: B. Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coxsackie viral infection can cause Hand-foot-and-mouth disease with associated viral meningitis, characterized by vesicular lesions on the palms, soles, and oral cavity, along with normal glucose and elevated lymphocytes in CSF.

questions.text: A 3-week neonate presents with ambiguous genitalia with Na+ - 127, K+ - 6 meq with a BP of 50/22 mm Hg. Along with IV fluids, what specific management is done? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hydrocortisone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Hydrocortisone is the first-line treatment for congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) with 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which presents with ambiguous genitalia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypotension in neonates.

questions.text: At what age does a child attain half-height of the adult height? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 20-24 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Children typically attain half of their adult height by 20-24 months, a critical milestone in early childhood growth and development.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with sensorineural hearing loss and eye defects presents to the OPD with hematuria. His renal biopsy on light microscopy was normal. Family history reveals the maternal uncle had Gr 5 CKD and is undergoing dialysis. Which of the following would be the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Alport syndrome.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by hematuria, sensorineural hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities, with characteristic findings on electron microscopy, including a "basket-weave" appearance of the glomerular basement membrane.

questions.text: The given chest X-ray is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tetralogy of Fallot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The boot-shaped heart on a chest X-ray is indicative of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), a congenital heart defect characterized by pulmonary stenosis, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: The patient presented with symptoms of fever, body ache, and joint pain, and was treated with NSAIDs. Subsequently, a few days later, the patient developed brownish pigmentation on the nose. What is the probable diagnosis? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chikungunya

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the context of fever, body ache, and joint pain , followed by the development of brownish pigmentation on the nose, Chikungunya is the probable diagnosis, as it can present with persistent joint pain and hyperpigmentation, particularly in regions where the virus is endemic.
  • ➤ fever, body ache, and joint pain
  • ➤ brownish pigmentation
  • ➤ Chikungunya
  • ➤ joint pain
  • ➤ hyperpigmentation,
  • ➤ endemic.
  • ➤ Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 118, Page no 118.11
  • ➤ Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 118, Page no 118.11
  • ➤ HARRISONS PRINCIPLES OF INTERNAL MEDICINE 21 ST EDITION PAGE 141-142, 1633
  • ➤ HARRISONS PRINCIPLES OF INTERNAL MEDICINE 21 ST EDITION PAGE 141-142, 1633

questions.text: The hormone that does not play a role in the growth of the fetus is: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Growth hormone.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Growth hormone does not play a significant role in fetal growth, which is primarily regulated by insulin, thyroxine, and glucocorticoids.

questions.text: What is the ideal route of drug delivery during neonatal resuscitation? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The umbilical vein is the preferred route for drug delivery during neonatal resuscitation. This method is favored because veins in the scalp or extremities can be difficult to access in emergency situations. The umbilical vein provides a reliable and quick access point for administering medications and fluids.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Intraosseous - Typically used in older children and adults when intravenous access is not possible, but not preferred in neonates during resuscitation.
  • • Option
  • • A. Intraosseous
  • • Option C. Through peripheral vein - Peripheral veins are harder to access quickly in a resuscitation scenario involving neonates.
  • • Option
  • • C. Through peripheral vein
  • • Option D. Through umbilical artery - This is not used for drug delivery; it is primarily used for blood gas analysis and monitoring.
  • • Option
  • • D. Through umbilical artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During neonatal resuscitation, the umbilical vein is the preferred route for drug delivery due to its quick and reliable access.

questions.text: Which of the following Carbapenems has highest risk of causing seizures? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Imipenem

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Imipenem carries the highest risk of inducing seizures among the carbapenem antibiotics, particularly in patients with renal impairment or a history of epilepsy. Proper dosage adjustments and careful monitoring are essential to minimize this risk.
  • ➤ Imipenem carries the highest risk of inducing seizures among the carbapenem antibiotics, particularly in patients with renal impairment or a history of epilepsy. Proper dosage adjustments and careful monitoring are essential to minimize this risk.

questions.text: The daughter of a woman who received diethylstilbestrol during her pregnancy is at higher risk for? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Clear cell adenocarcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is a synthetic estrogen that was previously prescribed to pregnant women to prevent miscarriages and other pregnancy complications. It was later discovered to be a teratogen and is no longer used. Exposure to DES in utero is known to cause the following conditions: In girls : T-shaped uterus Cockscomb cervix Vaginal and cervical clear cell adenocarcinoma In boys : Micropenis Hypospadias Undescended testes
  • • Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is a synthetic estrogen that was previously prescribed to pregnant women to prevent miscarriages and other pregnancy complications. It was later discovered to be a teratogen and is no longer used.
  • • Diethylstilbestrol (DES)
  • • Exposure to DES in utero is known to cause the following conditions: In girls : T-shaped uterus Cockscomb cervix Vaginal and cervical clear cell adenocarcinoma In boys : Micropenis Hypospadias Undescended testes
  • • In girls : T-shaped uterus Cockscomb cervix Vaginal and cervical clear cell adenocarcinoma In boys : Micropenis Hypospadias Undescended testes
  • • In girls : T-shaped uterus Cockscomb cervix Vaginal and cervical clear cell adenocarcinoma
  • • In girls
  • • T-shaped uterus Cockscomb cervix Vaginal and cervical clear cell adenocarcinoma
  • • T-shaped uterus
  • • Cockscomb cervix
  • • Vaginal and cervical clear cell adenocarcinoma
  • • In boys : Micropenis Hypospadias Undescended testes
  • • In boys
  • • Micropenis Hypospadias Undescended testes
  • • Micropenis
  • • Hypospadias
  • • Undescended testes
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma : Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of cervical cancer. It arises from the ectocervix, at the squamocolumnar junction. This type of cancer is not specifically associated with DES exposure.
  • • Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma
  • • Option C. Adenocarcinoma : Adenocarcinoma arises from the endocervix and is not specifically linked to DES exposure.
  • • Option C. Adenocarcinoma
  • • Option D. Sarcoma botryoides : Sarcoma botryoides is a type of rhabdomyosarcoma that arises from the cervix. It presents as a pinkish polypoidal growth filling up the vagina completely and causes blood-tinged watery discharge. It is not associated with DES exposure.
  • • Option D. Sarcoma botryoides

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DES exposure in utero is specifically associated with an increased risk of clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina and cervix.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg42
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg42

questions.text: Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway: ( INICET Nov 2020) Cochlear nucleus Spiral ganglion Superior olivary nucleus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2 - 1 - 3 - 4 - 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA). Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve Cochlear Nucleus Superior Olivary nucleus Lateral lemniscus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body Auditory cortex The spiral ganglion situated in Rosenthal's canal contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve which ends in the cochlear nuclei.
  • ➤ The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA). Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve Cochlear Nucleus Superior Olivary nucleus Lateral lemniscus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body Auditory cortex
  • ➤ Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve Cochlear Nucleus Superior Olivary nucleus Lateral lemniscus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body Auditory cortex
  • ➤ Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve
  • ➤ Cochlear Nucleus
  • ➤ Superior Olivary nucleus
  • ➤ Lateral lemniscus
  • ➤ Inferior colliculus
  • ➤ Medial geniculate body
  • ➤ Auditory cortex
  • ➤ The spiral ganglion situated in Rosenthal's canal contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve which ends in the cochlear nuclei.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for the prophylaxis of motion sickness? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Promethazine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Promethazine is used for the prophylaxis of motion sickness due to its strong antihistamine, anticholinergic, sedative, and antiemetic properties. Second-generation antihistamines like cetirizine, misolastine, and loratadine are not effective for this purpose due to their lack of these properties.

questions.text: A patient was sputum negative for tuberculosis, but chest X-ray was suggestive of tuberculosis. Which is the next step according to RNTCP? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CBNAAT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients with negative sputum smears but chest X-ray findings suggestive of TB, CBNAAT is the recommended next diagnostic step under RNTCP guidelines.

questions.text: A pediatrician is assessing the growth milestones of a child during a routine health visit. The parents are curious about the child’s growth pattern and wonder how close the child is to reaching significant growth milestones. The pediatrician explains that certain ages are critical for reaching specific percentages of adult height. At what age does a child typically attain half of their adult height?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Children generally attain half of their adult height between the ages of 18 to 24 months. Monitoring growth accurately during this period is crucial for assessing normal development and identifying any growth concerns early.
  • • Growth Milestone: Children attain half of their adult height by 20-24 months of age.
  • • Growth Milestone:
  • • Measuring Techniques:
  • • Measuring Techniques:
  • • For children under 2 years, length is measured using an infantometer or rigid measuring table. The infant’s head is held against a fixed headboard, legs are straightened, and feet are positioned at right angles with toes pointing upwards. Measurement techniques like using cloth tapes or measuring on a mattress are inaccurate and not recommended.
  • • infantometer or rigid measuring table.
  • • For children over 2 years, height is measured by asking the child to stand upright with heels, buttocks, shoulder blades, and head against a vertical surface, using a stadiometer or measuring rod. The child should look forward, and the headpiece should be firmly placed over the head to compress the hair.
  • • Growth Monitoring:
  • • Growth Monitoring:
  • • Plotting height and weight on a growth chart helps determine if the child is growing normally for their age and identifies factors affecting growth. Growth charts are routinely used during vaccination visits, minor illness visits, and school health programs.
  • • Regular monitoring of growth helps detect potential growth problems early, such as growth delays, excessive weight gain, or failure to thrive, allowing for timely intervention and management.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Children typically reach half of their adult height between 18-24 months. Accurate measurement and regular monitoring during this critical period help ensure the child is growing normally, facilitating early detection and management of any growth-related issues.

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV patient presented with a painful lesion, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Kaposi sarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kaposi sarcoma should be suspected in HIV patients presenting with violaceous lesions on the skin or mucous membranes. It is an AIDS-defining condition associated with HHV-8 infection.

questions.text: All of the following are components of Beck's cognitive theory of depression except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Introjection is not a component of Beck's cognitive theory of depression; it is associated with psychoanalytic theory, which focuses on internalized feelings towards an object, such as a parent, and is less commonly used in contemporary understanding of depression.

questions.text: An oncologist is discussing with a colleague about the latest evidence-based approaches to treating non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The KEYNOTE-189 trial comes up in their conversation. Which of the following accurately describes the focus of the KEYNOTE-189 trial? ( INICET May 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: The trial investigated NSCLC treatment using a combination of pembrolizumab and chemotherapy.

options.label: B
options.text: The trial focused solely on the use of pembrolizumab for treating NSCLC.

options.label: C
options.text: The study explored the efficacy of combining nivolumab and chemotherapy for NSCLC.

options.label: D
options.text: The trial looked at nivolumab as a treatment option for NSCLC.

questions.correct_answer: A. The trial investigated NSCLC treatment using a combination of pembrolizumab and chemotherapy.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. The trial investigated NSCLC treatment using a combination of pembrolizumab and chemotherapy.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following trait is a feature of the female skull? ( AIIMS May 2018)

options.label: B
options.text: Frontal and maxillary sinuses are larger

options.label: C
options.text: Frontal and parietal eminences are larger

questions.correct_answer: C. Frontal and parietal eminences are larger
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Frontal and parietal eminences are larger

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ General differences between male and female bones: There are some general features which help to differentiate male and female bones. These are applicable to most bones, hence no need to remember separately for each bone. These are
  • ➤ General differences between male and female bones:
  • ➤ Size: Male bones tend are larger than female bones.
  • ➤ Size:
  • ➤ Texture: The texture of male bones can be rougher and more rugged due to increased muscle attachment areas.
  • ➤ Texture:
  • ➤ Articular Surface Size: Male bones may have larger articular surfaces compared to females .
  • ➤ Articular Surface Size:
  • ➤ .
  • ➤ Bone Markings: Bony markings where muscles and ligaments attach are more prominent in males.
  • ➤ Bone Markings:
  • ➤ So for individual bones, just remember the specific features, instead of general features

questions.text: Which bacterial toxin acts by interfering with EF-2 function? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Diphtheria

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylating elongation factor 2 (EF-2), blocking its function.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Clostridium : Produces toxins, but they do not target EF-2.
  • • Option B. Clostridium
  • • Option C. Bacillus : Associated with different toxins not affecting EF-2.
  • • Option C. Bacillus
  • • Option D. Vibrio : Known for cholera toxin affecting intestinal secretion, not EF-2.
  • • Option D. Vibrio

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diphtheria toxin uniquely targets EF-2, crucial for understanding its mechanism of action in causing disease by inhibiting protein synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a second line anti-tubercular drug? ( INICET May 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Ethionamide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethionamide is a second-line anti-tubercular drug used in the management of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB), whereas isoniazid is a first-line drug, and acyclovir and vancomycin are not used for tuberculosis treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following regimen is commonly used in the treatment of retinoblastoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Vincristine, carboplatin and etoposide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most commonly used chemotherapy regimen for retinoblastoma includes vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide. This combination is effective in reducing tumor size and facilitating further local treatment options.

questions.text: A 14-month-old child presents with a history of repeated blood transfusions, with the last transfusion given at 9 months of age. Laboratory evaluation reveals hemoglobin of 6.3 g/dL. Peripheral blood smear shows target cells, as depicted in the image. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following investigations is used for a definitive diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation of severe anemia requiring repeated blood transfusions and the presence of target cells on the blood smear is highly suggestive of thalassemia, an inherited hemoglobin disorder. Thalassemia affects the production of alpha or beta-globin chains, leading to ineffective erythropoiesis and hemolysis.
  • • Thalassemia Diagnosis: The severity of the disease correlates with the number of affected globin chain genes. Each individual normally has 4 alpha-chain genes and 2 beta-chain genes. Mutations in these genes can lead to alpha- or beta-thalassemia, with varying severity based on the number of mutated genes.
  • • Thalassemia Diagnosis:
  • • Definitive Diagnosis: The definitive test for diagnosing thalassemia is globin gene sequencing , which identifies specific genetic mutations affecting globin chain production. This test provides accurate diagnosis and helps guide management and genetic counseling.
  • • Definitive Diagnosis:
  • • globin gene sequencing
  • • Hemoglobin Levels in Thalassemia:
  • • Hemoglobin Levels in Thalassemia:
  • • Normal: HbA = 95%, HbA2 = 3.5%, HbF = 1.5%
  • • Beta-thalassemia trait: HbA = 90%, HbA2 = 5%, HbF = 5%
  • • Beta-thalassemia intermedia: HbA = 45%, HbA2 = 5%, HbF = 50%
  • • Screening Tests:
  • • Screening Tests:
  • • Hemoglobin Electrophoresis: Commonly used for newborn screening and identifies abnormal hemoglobin patterns, but it is not definitive for diagnosing specific thalassemia mutations.
  • • Hemoglobin Electrophoresis:
  • • High-Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC): Another screening test for detecting abnormal hemoglobin levels but not specific for identifying genetic mutations.
  • • High-Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC):
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Complete blood count (CBC): Provides initial information on anemia but does not confirm the diagnosis of thalassemia.
  • • Option A) Complete blood count (CBC):
  • • Option B) Hemoglobin electrophoresis: Useful for identifying abnormal hemoglobin patterns but not definitive for thalassemia diagnosis.
  • • Option B) Hemoglobin electrophoresis:
  • • Option C) Bone marrow biopsy: Not typically used for diagnosing thalassemia; more relevant for other hematological conditions like leukemia.
  • • Option C) Bone marrow biopsy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Globin gene sequencing is the definitive diagnostic test for thalassemia, providing precise identification of the genetic mutations affecting globin chain production. This test is essential for confirming the diagnosis, guiding treatment, and offering genetic counseling to affected families.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the Pediatrics OPD with the complaints of several episodes of melena. On physical examination, there was eczematous rash over the skin with multiple red pin-point hemorrhagic spots. His Hemogram reveals low platelet count and normal RBC and WBC counts. What is the next best investigation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) WASP gene mutation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome should be suspected in a pediatric patient with thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent bleeding episodes, and the next best step is to investigate for a WASP gene mutation.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 439-440
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 439-440

questions.text: In Which of the following pathways, cyclooxygenase is involved? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Prostaglandin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cyclooxygenase is involved in the prostaglandin synthesis pathway, converting arachidonic acid into prostaglandins, which are key mediators of inflammation, pain, and other physiological responses.

  • ➤ 3.9 - By 2030, reduce the number of deaths, illnesses form hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination.

questions.text: An epileptic patient on levetiracetam has been seizure-free for 2 years. But he develops agitation and anger issues interfering with his day-to-day activities as a result of the drug intake. Which of the following measures is to be taken next? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Slowly taper the drug over next 6 months

options.label: B
options.text: Continue levetiracetam since a 5-year seizure free interval is needed

options.label: C
options.text: Stop levetiracetam and start on a different anti-epileptic

options.label: D
options.text: Discontinue the drug as he is seizure free

questions.correct_answer: A. Slowly taper the drug over next 6 months
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Slowly taper the drug over next 6 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a patient on levetiracetam experiences significant psychiatric side effects, the best approach is to slowly taper the medication over several months to prevent rebound seizures and address the side effects.

questions.text: In which disease among the following, Chloride level in sweat is evaluated? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cystic fibrosis

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement about Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) ? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Nodular sclerosis HL commonly involves the mediastinum

options.label: D
options.text: Commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring

questions.correct_answer: D. Commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hodgkin lymphoma typically involves the cervical, mediastinal, axillary, and inguinal lymph nodes. The involvement of the Waldeyer ring is more characteristic of non-Hodgkin lymphoma

questions.text: A 25-year-old female came with complaints of greenish discharge per vagina and on examination she had a strawberry cervix. Which of the following is the treatment for her? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Metronidazole

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation of greenish-yellow discharge and a strawberry cervix is characteristic of trichomoniasis. Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. The diagnostic feature of trichomoniasis includes the presence of motile flagellate organisms on a wet mount microscopy.
  • • Characteristic findings: Colour of discharge: Greenish yellow On examination: Strawberry cervix and vagina pH: >5 Diagnosis (Wet mount): Motile flagellate organism
  • • Characteristic findings: Colour of discharge: Greenish yellow On examination: Strawberry cervix and vagina pH: >5 Diagnosis (Wet mount): Motile flagellate organism
  • • Characteristic findings:
  • • Colour of discharge: Greenish yellow On examination: Strawberry cervix and vagina pH: >5 Diagnosis (Wet mount): Motile flagellate organism
  • • Colour of discharge: Greenish yellow
  • • Colour of discharge:
  • • On examination: Strawberry cervix and vagina
  • • On examination:
  • • pH: >5
  • • pH:
  • • Diagnosis (Wet mount): Motile flagellate organism
  • • Diagnosis (Wet mount):
  • • Treatment:
  • • Treatment:
  • • The recommended treatment for trichomoniasis is metronidazole. It can be administered as a single dose of 2g or 200mg TDS for 7 days.
  • • The recommended treatment for trichomoniasis is metronidazole. It can be administered as a single dose of 2g or 200mg TDS for 7 days.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Doxycycline: This antibiotic is used to treat various bacterial infections, including some sexually transmitted infections, but it is not the treatment of choice for trichomoniasis.
  • • Option A. Doxycycline:
  • • Option B. Amoxicillin: This antibiotic is used for bacterial infections but is not effective against trichomoniasis.
  • • Option B. Amoxicillin:
  • • Option C. Fluconazole: This antifungal medication is used to treat candidiasis, not trichomoniasis.
  • • Option C. Fluconazole:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Strawberry cervix and greenish-yellow vaginal discharge are characteristic of trichomoniasis, which is treated with metronidazole.
  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Strawberry cervix and vagina are characteristic of Trichomoniasis
  • ➤ Strawberry cervix and vagina are characteristic of Trichomoniasis
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 164, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 164, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: A newborn infant of a diabetic mother is being monitored in the neonatal unit due to the increased risk of complications associated with maternal diabetes. The infant appears irritable, has poor feeding, and initial blood glucose is measured at 60 mg/dL. Recognizing that infants born to diabetic mothers are at risk for various metabolic disturbances, the healthcare team decides to perform further evaluations. Which additional investigation is most appropriate for this infant?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Infants born to diabetic mothers are at increased risk for several metabolic disturbances, including hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia. Although this infant’s blood glucose is within an acceptable range, it is important to assess serum calcium levels because hypocalcemia is common in these infants.
  • • Risk Factors for Infants of Diabetic Mothers:
  • • Risk Factors for Infants of Diabetic Mothers:
  • • Infants of diabetic mothers are prone to hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia due to the maternal metabolic influences and adaptations during fetal development.
  • • Hypocalcemia in Neonates:
  • • Hypocalcemia in Neonates:
  • • Hypocalcemia is defined as low levels of total serum calcium, with a cutoff of less than 8 mg/dL for term infants and less than 7 mg/dL for preterm infants.
  • • This condition occurs due to lower levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) in infants of diabetic mothers compared to normal infants after birth. In utero, higher levels of serum ionized calcium may suppress the fetal parathyroid glands, contributing to this condition.
  • • Clinical Implications of Hypocalcemia:
  • • Clinical Implications of Hypocalcemia:
  • • If left undiagnosed and untreated, hypocalcemia can lead to neurological symptoms, including irritability, poor feeding, seizures, or other neurologic deficits.
  • • Evaluation of Infants at Risk:
  • • Evaluation of Infants at Risk:
  • • In infants born to diabetic mothers, it is recommended to estimate the serum calcium level to rule out hypocalcemia, even if initial symptoms are subtle or not immediately severe.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B) Serum potassium level: Potassium levels are not specifically affected in infants of diabetic mothers, making this less relevant for immediate evaluation.
  • • Option B) Serum potassium level:
  • • Option C) Serum bilirubin level: Elevated bilirubin is common in newborns but does not directly relate to maternal diabetes and the immediate concerns of hypocalcemia.
  • • Option C) Serum bilirubin level:
  • • Option D) Serum creatinine level: Used to assess kidney function, but it is not directly relevant to the primary metabolic risks associated with infants of diabetic mothers.
  • • Option D) Serum creatinine level:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Infants born to diabetic mothers should be evaluated for hypocalcemia due to their increased risk, which is influenced by maternal metabolic factors and fetal adaptations. Early detection through serum calcium measurement is essential to prevent neurological complications and ensure proper management.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the emergency room in the early stage of labor with adequate uterine contractions. On per vaginal examination, a gynecoid pelvis is felt, the membranes are ruptured, and the vertex is felt in the right occipito-posterior position. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Normal vaginal delivery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Normal vaginal delivery: Assuming the patient has no other complications, such as fetal distress or cephalopelvic disproportion, the given features of right occipito-posterior presentation with a favorable pelvis (gynecoid) and adequate uterine contractions can be managed by normal vaginal delivery. In 90% of circumstances with a favorable pelvis and strong uterine contractions, without any complications, the occipito-posterior position can undergo the mechanism of normal labor. The patient can be closely monitored for the progress of normal vaginal delivery. However, if complications arise or labor stalls, alternative methods such as vacuum-assisted delivery or forceps delivery may be considered. A cesarean section would only be necessary if there were complications that prevented a safe vaginal delivery.
  • • Normal vaginal delivery: Assuming the patient has no other complications, such as fetal distress or cephalopelvic disproportion, the given features of right occipito-posterior presentation with a favorable pelvis (gynecoid) and adequate uterine contractions can be managed by normal vaginal delivery. In 90% of circumstances with a favorable pelvis and strong uterine contractions, without any complications, the occipito-posterior position can undergo the mechanism of normal labor. The patient can be closely monitored for the progress of normal vaginal delivery. However, if complications arise or labor stalls, alternative methods such as vacuum-assisted delivery or forceps delivery may be considered. A cesarean section would only be necessary if there were complications that prevented a safe vaginal delivery.
  • • Normal vaginal delivery:
  • • Assuming the patient has no other complications, such as fetal distress or cephalopelvic disproportion, the given features of right occipito-posterior presentation with a favorable pelvis (gynecoid) and adequate uterine contractions can be managed by normal vaginal delivery. In 90% of circumstances with a favorable pelvis and strong uterine contractions, without any complications, the occipito-posterior position can undergo the mechanism of normal labor. The patient can be closely monitored for the progress of normal vaginal delivery. However, if complications arise or labor stalls, alternative methods such as vacuum-assisted delivery or forceps delivery may be considered. A cesarean section would only be necessary if there were complications that prevented a safe vaginal delivery.
  • • Assuming the patient has no other complications, such as fetal distress or cephalopelvic disproportion, the given features of right occipito-posterior presentation with a favorable pelvis (gynecoid) and adequate uterine contractions can be managed by normal vaginal delivery.
  • • In 90% of circumstances with a favorable pelvis and strong uterine contractions, without any complications, the occipito-posterior position can undergo the mechanism of normal labor.
  • • The patient can be closely monitored for the progress of normal vaginal delivery. However, if complications arise or labor stalls, alternative methods such as vacuum-assisted delivery or forceps delivery may be considered. A cesarean section would only be necessary if there were complications that prevented a safe vaginal delivery.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Vacuum-assisted delivery is generally considered when there is prolonged second stage of labor or fetal distress. In this case, since there are no complications mentioned and the pelvis is favorable, normal vaginal delivery is the preferred option.
  • • Option A. Vacuum-assisted delivery:
  • • Option B. Cesarean section: A cesarean section is usually considered when there is cephalopelvic disproportion, fetal distress, or failure to progress in labor. Given the favorable conditions in this scenario, a normal vaginal delivery is feasible.
  • • Option B. Cesarean section:
  • • Option D. Forceps delivery: Forceps delivery, like vacuum-assisted delivery, is used in cases of prolonged second stage of labor or when there is a need to expedite delivery. In the absence of such complications, normal vaginal delivery is the appropriate management.
  • • Option D. Forceps delivery:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Right occipito-posterior presentation with a favorable pelvis and adequate uterine contractions in a primigravida can be managed by closely monitoring for a normal vaginal delivery, provided there are no complications.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 89, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 89, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Which of the following tests cannot be used to assess nasal mucociliary clearance? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Electron microscopy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Test for mucociliary clearance is: Saccharin with or without color test in vivo - Saccharin or another substance is placed in the nose, and the speed of transport into the nasopharynx is measured to calculate mucociliary clearance. Radioisotope transport testing in vivo Measuring ciliary activity in vitro Nasal nitric oxide - Measuring exhaled nasal nitric oxide, which is mostly reduced in primary ciliary dyskinesia, is a good screening test for immotile-cilia syndrome with a good negative predictive value Scintigraphy is the nuclear medicine equivalent of the dye disappearance test to assess functional and anatomic obstruction Pulmonary radioaerosol mucociliary clearance: Mucociliary transport, which is reduced in these patients, can be measured in situ by administering an inhalation aerosol of colloid albumin or colloid sulfur tagged with technetium Tc 99. This test is generally not recommended owing to the high rate of false-positive results. The charcoal method - a very small amount of charcoal is placed behind the head of the inferior turbinate. The pharynx is then observed to detect the presence of charcoal. Less commonly used.
  • ➤ Test for mucociliary clearance is: Saccharin with or without color test in vivo - Saccharin or another substance is placed in the nose, and the speed of transport into the nasopharynx is measured to calculate mucociliary clearance. Radioisotope transport testing in vivo Measuring ciliary activity in vitro Nasal nitric oxide - Measuring exhaled nasal nitric oxide, which is mostly reduced in primary ciliary dyskinesia, is a good screening test for immotile-cilia syndrome with a good negative predictive value Scintigraphy is the nuclear medicine equivalent of the dye disappearance test to assess functional and anatomic obstruction Pulmonary radioaerosol mucociliary clearance: Mucociliary transport, which is reduced in these patients, can be measured in situ by administering an inhalation aerosol of colloid albumin or colloid sulfur tagged with technetium Tc 99. This test is generally not recommended owing to the high rate of false-positive results. The charcoal method - a very small amount of charcoal is placed behind the head of the inferior turbinate. The pharynx is then observed to detect the presence of charcoal. Less commonly used.
  • ➤ Saccharin with or without color test in vivo - Saccharin or another substance is placed in the nose, and the speed of transport into the nasopharynx is measured to calculate mucociliary clearance. Radioisotope transport testing in vivo Measuring ciliary activity in vitro Nasal nitric oxide - Measuring exhaled nasal nitric oxide, which is mostly reduced in primary ciliary dyskinesia, is a good screening test for immotile-cilia syndrome with a good negative predictive value Scintigraphy is the nuclear medicine equivalent of the dye disappearance test to assess functional and anatomic obstruction Pulmonary radioaerosol mucociliary clearance: Mucociliary transport, which is reduced in these patients, can be measured in situ by administering an inhalation aerosol of colloid albumin or colloid sulfur tagged with technetium Tc 99. This test is generally not recommended owing to the high rate of false-positive results. The charcoal method - a very small amount of charcoal is placed behind the head of the inferior turbinate. The pharynx is then observed to detect the presence of charcoal. Less commonly used.
  • ➤ Saccharin with or without color test in vivo - Saccharin or another substance is placed in the nose, and the speed of transport into the nasopharynx is measured to calculate mucociliary clearance.
  • ➤ Radioisotope transport testing in vivo
  • ➤ Measuring ciliary activity in vitro
  • ➤ Nasal nitric oxide - Measuring exhaled nasal nitric oxide, which is mostly reduced in primary ciliary dyskinesia, is a good screening test for immotile-cilia syndrome with a good negative predictive value
  • ➤ Scintigraphy is the nuclear medicine equivalent of the dye disappearance test to assess functional and anatomic obstruction
  • ➤ Pulmonary radioaerosol mucociliary clearance: Mucociliary transport, which is reduced in these patients, can be measured in situ by administering an inhalation aerosol of colloid albumin or colloid sulfur tagged with technetium Tc 99. This test is generally not recommended owing to the high rate of false-positive results.
  • ➤ The charcoal method - a very small amount of charcoal is placed behind the head of the inferior turbinate. The pharynx is then observed to detect the presence of charcoal. Less commonly used.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman on oral contraceptives for the past 6 months presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea. What would be the best method of assessing the gestational age of this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.correct_answer: A. Crown rump length by USG
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Crown rump length by USG

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Crown-Rump Length (CRL) by Ultrasound:
  • • Crown-Rump Length (CRL) by Ultrasound:
  • • The most accurate method for determining gestational age in the first trimester is by measuring the Crown-Rump Length (CRL) on ultrasound. This method is reliable as it directly measures the embryo or fetus and provides a precise gestational age.
  • • The most accurate method for determining gestational age in the first trimester is by measuring the Crown-Rump Length (CRL) on ultrasound. This method is reliable as it directly measures the embryo or fetus and provides a precise gestational age.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Adding 280 days to the Last Menstrual Period (LMP):
  • • Option B. Adding 280 days to the Last Menstrual Period (LMP):
  • • This method, known as Naegele’s rule, is commonly used but assumes a regular 28-day menstrual cycle and may not be accurate for women with irregular cycles or those using contraceptives. It is less reliable in this patient who has been on oral contraceptives, which can alter the regularity of menstrual cycles.
  • • This method, known as Naegele’s rule, is commonly used but assumes a regular 28-day menstrual cycle and may not be accurate for women with irregular cycles or those using contraceptives.
  • • It is less reliable in this patient who has been on oral contraceptives, which can alter the regularity of menstrual cycles.
  • • Option C. Fundus Examination:
  • • Option C. Fundus Examination:
  • • Palpation of the uterine fundus is a physical examination method to estimate gestational age. However, it is less accurate in the first trimester and typically used in the second and third trimesters.
  • • Palpation of the uterine fundus is a physical examination method to estimate gestational age. However, it is less accurate in the first trimester and typically used in the second and third trimesters.
  • • Option D. Adding 256 days to the LMP:
  • • Option D. Adding 256 days to the LMP:
  • • This method is not standard practice and is less commonly used compared to adding 280 days to the LMP. It would be even less reliable in this patient who has been on oral contraceptives.
  • • This method is not standard practice and is less commonly used compared to adding 280 days to the LMP.
  • • It would be even less reliable in this patient who has been on oral contraceptives.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most accurate method for determining gestational age in the first trimester is the measurement of Crown-Rump Length (CRL) on ultrasound.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 475, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 475, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: What advice do you give to a mother who is using medications during lactation? (AIIMS MAY 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: No advice as most of drug are not present in breast milk

options.label: C
options.text: Tell the mother to feed when it is least efficacious

options.label: D
options.text: To feed just before the next dose, when the plasma concentration of the drug would be the least

questions.correct_answer: D. To feed just before the next dose, when the plasma concentration of the drug would be the least
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. To feed just before the next dose, when the plasma concentration of the drug would be the least

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best advice for a lactating mother using medications is to breastfeed just before taking her next dose of medication. This practice ensures that the drug's plasma concentration is at its lowest during breastfeeding, thereby reducing the amount of drug that passes into the breast milk and minimizing exposure to the infant.

questions.text: I-125 labelled albumin is used for measurement of: ( AIIMS May 2019)
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Plasma volume

questions.text: A 14-month-old boy was diagnosed with Hemophilus influenza meningitis. The initial treatment plan was to start on ampicillin but later was shifted to ceftriaxone. What could be the probable reason? ( INICET Nov 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Hemophilus alters penicillin binding protein sites, hence resistant to ampicillin

options.label: B
options.text: Easier to administer IV ceftriaxone than IV ampicillin

options.label: C
options.text: Cotrimoxazole is the drug of choice, but patient is allergic to sulfa drugs

options.label: D
options.text: Hemophilus produces beta lactamase, hence resistant to ampicillin

questions.correct_answer: D. Hemophilus produces beta lactamase, hence resistant to ampicillin
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Hemophilus produces beta lactamase, hence resistant to ampicillin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary reason for switching from ampicillin to ceftriaxone in the treatment of Hemophilus influenzae meningitis is the production of beta-lactamase by H. influenzae, which renders the bacteria resistant to ampicillin. Ceftriaxone is more resistant to beta-lactamase and provides effective CNS penetration, making it a more suitable choice for treating bacterial meningitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of infection post-solid organ transplantation in an Indian setting? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most prevalent and clinically significant viral infection in the post-solid organ transplant setting in India, necessitating targeted prophylaxis and monitoring protocols to mitigate its risks.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Critical Care Nephrology /Chapter 95

questions.text: Purkinje cells of cerebellum relay into: ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Dentate nucleus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The cerebellum's purkinje cells relay information to the dentate nucleus, one of the deep cerebellar nuclei.
  • • It is the cerebellum's distinguishing cell. It is a large flask-shaped cell. Climbing fibres from the inferior olivary nucleus stimulate it. This cell's main output is inhibitory in nature and is directed at cerebellar nuclei. These are the most important output neurons.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Caudate Nucleus : It's one of the structures that make up the basal ganglia in the brain. The caudate nucleus has a long, C-shaped structure and is located laterally in the brain, near the lateral ventricles. It plays roles in various functions like voluntary movement control, learning, memory, and emotion. Purkinje cells do not primarily relay into the caudate nucleus.
  • • Option A.
  • • Caudate Nucleus
  • • Option B . Lentiform Nucleus : Another component of the basal ganglia, the lentiform nucleus is located deep within the brain and is laterally placed in relation to the thalamus. The lentiform nucleus is made up of two structures: the putamen and the globus pallidus. It's involved in movement regulation and other functions. Purkinje cells do not have a direct relay into the lentiform nucleus.
  • • Option B
  • • Lentiform Nucleus
  • • Option D. Red Nucleus : Found in the midbrain, the red nucleus has a reddish hue due to its rich blood supply and the presence of iron. It plays a role in motor coordination, particularly in the coordination of limb movements. While the red nucleus does receive input from the cerebellum, the primary relay from Purkinje cells is to the deep cerebellar nuclei, not directly to the red nucleus. The dentate nucleus, in turn, can send projections to the red nucleus.
  • • Option D.
  • • Red Nucleus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dentate Nucleus is one of the deep cerebellar nuclei and is situated within the white matter of the cerebellum. The dentate nucleus is the largest of the deep cerebellar nuclei and plays a role in the planning, initiation, and control of voluntary movements.
  • ➤ Dentate Nucleus
  • ➤ Purkinje cells in the cerebellar cortex send inhibitory projections to the deep cerebellar nuclei, including the dentate nucleus. This is the main output pathway for the cerebellar cortex.
